name: adiantum-pedatum
distribution: Moist forests in eastern North America
wildlife-value: It provides excellent ground cover and parts are used in bird nest construction.
particularly-resistant-to-insects/diseas: highly resistant to damage from deer; heavy shade
light: Deep shade (Less than 2 hours to no direct sunlight)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: No fruit; reproduces via spores (which are a light brown) can be at times seen on the edges of each fan-shaped frond.
leaf-description: This plant has airy, fan-shaped, deep blue-green fronds and circular or horseshoe-shaped rachis and shell-shaped pinnae.  1-5-pinnate, arching, weakly glaucous beneath, membraneous; pinnae often decompound, flabellately branched; pinnules/leaflets somewhat triangular, broadly cuneate, lobed, sterile lobes cut deeply; stipe/petiole wiry, shiny black or tinged purple. Spores or sori (which are a light brown and elongated) can be at times seen on the edges of each fan-shaped frond and covered by a revolute, pinnule, marginal flap
